\title{Exactly solvable spin chain models in BDI class of topological superconductors}

\author{S. A. Jafari}
\email{akbar.jafari@gmail.com}
\affiliation{Department of Physics, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran 11155-9161, Iran}
\affiliation{Center of excellence for Complex Systems and Condensed Matter (CSCM), Sharif University of Technology, Tehran 1458889694, Iran}
\author{Farhad  Shahbazi}
\email{shahbazi@cc.iut.ac.ir}
\thanks{Both authors have equal contribution.}
\affiliation{Department of Physics, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84156, Iran}


\begin{abstract}
We present an exactly solvable extension of the quantum XY chain with longer range
multi-spin interactions.
Topological phase transitions of the model are classified in terms of the number of
Majorana zero modes which are in turn related to an integer winding number. 
We further find a general relation between the winding number and the number of Majorana fermions
at the ends of an open chain.
The present class of exactly solvable models belong to the BDI class in the 
Altland-Zirnbauer classification (A. Altland, M. R. Zirnbauer, Phys. Rev. B (1997) {\bf 55} 1142)
of topological superconductors. We show that time reversal (TR) symmetry of the spin variables 
translates into a peculiar particle-hole transformation in the language of Jordan-Wigner (JW) 
fermions that is accompanied by a $\pi$ shift in the wave vector ($\pi$PH). Presence of $\pi$PH
symmetry restricts the winding number of TR symmetric extensions of XY to odd integers.
The $\pi$PH operator may serve in further detailed classification of topological superconductors.
\end{abstract}

Exactly solvable models although mostly limited to one spatial dimension are
cornerstones of theoretical physics in that, they form the backbone of 
our understanding of many-body physics. 
The original expression of Hamiltonian
can be in terms of fermions, bosons, or spin degrees of freedom, while the
exact solution may reveal presence of other types of emergent excitations in the
spectrum~\cite{LSM}. As an example on which we will focus in the present paper,
the XY model although originally written in terms of spin operators, the spin-spin interactions
turn out to produce a spectrum described in terms of the 
Jordan-Wigner (JW) fermions~\cite{Mattis2006}. The anisotropy of the XY chain 
generates p-wave superconducting pairing between spinless JW fermions
leading to unpaired Majorana fermion (MF) at each end of an open chain~\cite{Kitaev2001}.

Adding further neighbor XY couplings in general spoils the exact solvability
because the JW transformation incorporates appropriate (non-local) phase strings in order to
fulfill anti-commutation algebra~\cite{Mattis2006}. In the context of the
Ising in a transverse field (ITF) model it was recently 
shown that adding appropriately engineered three-spin
interactions can still leave it exactly solvable~\cite{Raghu2011}.
On the other hand the quantum XY and (ITF) models are related by 
duality transformation~\cite{Savit,Henkel}. Therefore we expect similar extensions 
to work for the XY model.

nexttext:
which has been plotted in left panel of Fig.~\ref{boundary.fig}.
It is remarkable that the phase boundary 
is given in terms of ratios $J_2/J_1$ and $\lambda_2/\lambda_1$. 
It is because in Eq.~\eqref{epsdelta.eqn} only these rations are relevant.
This property is also general and applies for all possible generalizations:
The phase diagram is determined only in terms of the rations $J_r/J_1$ and $\lambda_r/\lambda_1$.
In the left panel of Fig.~\ref{boundary.fig} each region is labeled by
a winding number $n_W$. This topological invariant corresponds to the number
of times the unit circle is covered by the vector $(\Delta_k,{\varepsilon}_k)$ as
$k$ varies across the first Brillouin zone (1BZ)~\cite{Alicea}. These vectors are represented by 
black arrows in Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig}. Panels (a)-(e) of Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig}
are constructed for the $(\lambda_2/\lambda_1,J_2/J_1)$ values indicated in top-left
of each panel. The winding pattern of arrows and the global variation profile of $\phi_k$ does not
change as long as the phase boundaries of Fig.~\ref{boundary.fig} are not crossed.
This means that $n_W$ is a topological invariant~\cite{BernevigBook}.
For the 3XY model five possible values $n_W=0,\pm 1, \pm 2$ can be extracted 
from Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig} which are used to label regions of Fig.~\ref{boundary.fig}.
Note that no local order parameter such as magnetization can distinguish
between these regions in the sense that all of them correspond to fully
spin-polarized configurations.
The phase with $n_W=0$ is adiabatically connected to the trivially gapped phase
that can be reached by an applied field $h\to\pm\infty$ that couples to ${\sigma^z}$ 
without gap closing. This makes the $n_W=0$ region topologically trivial. This is
while the other phases with $n_W\ne 0$ are separated from the trivially gapped phase
by a gap closing. The panel (f) of Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig} corresponds to 
$\lambda_2=J_2=0$. At this point of the phase diagram, every $\lambda_1\ne 0$ 
is adiabatically connected to the Ising limit $\lambda_1=1$. This is 
why the phase boundary~\eqref{bndry.eqn} is determined by the ratio $\lambda_2/\lambda_1$.

Let us show that for a quite general $r$ the nXY model falls into BDI class~\cite{Schnyder2008} 
which in turn allows for winding number classification.  
First let us check the TR symmetry. For spinless fermions TR operator $\cal T$ is simply a complex
conjugation. Using the Nambu space representation, Eq.~\eqref{H-sq.eqn} we have 
${\cal T}{\vec h}(k){\cal T}={\vec h}(-k)$
which represents the TR symmetry of the Hamiltonian in fermionic representation.  
Now defining the operator ${\cal C}=\tau_{x}K$ as the particle-hole transformation,
one finds ${\cal C} {\vec h}(k) {\cal C}=-{\vec h}(k)$ that checks the {\em the} PH symmetry. 
Finally for the chiral symmetry we have, 
${\vec h}(k){\cal C}{\cal T}=-{\cal C}{\cal T}{\vec h}(k)$.

by the sliding PH symmetry, $\pi$PH. To proceed further let us first elucidate the
meaning of $\pi$PH in the language of MFs: If we represent the JW "electron" and "hole" 
operators as $c^\dagger_j=a_j+ib_j$ and $h_j=a'_j-ib'_j$ and if we search for MFs 
with vanishing $b,b'$ component, then every zero mode solution 
$(A_1,0,A_2,0,\ldots)$ is mapped by $\pi$PH to a {\em partner} MF $(A'_1,0,A'_2,0,\ldots)$
with $A'_j=-(-1)^j A_j$. 

  For even values of $r$ where odd number of spin variables are added to the
XY model, consider any point in the phase diagram (see left panel of Fig.~\ref{MFcolor.fig}) 
with given number $n_M$ of MFs. Obviously the generalized $r+1$-spin interaction
breaks TR symmetry. However the overall minus arising from TR transformation can be absorbed
by the transformation $(\lambda_r,J_r)\to -(\lambda_r,J_r)$. This means that for every
MF at point $(\lambda_1,J_1,\lambda_r,J_r)$ in the phase diagram, its partner MF
is at pint $(\lambda_1,J_1,-\lambda_r,-J_r)$. For odd values of $r$ on the other hand,
there are even number of spins, and the TR does not produce any 
minus sign in the Hamiltonian 
and hence corresponding to each MF at 
any point $(\lambda_1,J_1,\lambda_r,J_r)$, the partner MF also exists at the same
point in the parameter space. 
These can also be seen directly from Eq.~\eqref{secul.eqn}. For odd $r$ this equation
becomes an equation of degree $r$ in terms of $X=x^2$. Therefore for every solution
$x$, the solution $-x$ also exists. Then the form $A_j\sim x^j$ implies that if 
$x$ corresponds to a MF solution, its its partner corresponds to $-x$. Hence for 
odd $r$ there are always even number of MFs possible. For even $r$, the secular 
equation~\eqref{secul.eqn} maps to itself under simultaneous change of $x\to -x$
and $(\lambda_r,J_r)\to -(\lambda_r,J_r)$.

Now consider an arbitrary point in the phase diagram 
corresponding to pairing amplitudes $\{\lambda_n\}$.
Since the resulting JW Hamiltonian~\eqref{JW.eqn} is TR symmetric, 
the action of TR is simply $i\to -i$ which can be absorbed by 
$\{\lambda_i\}\to\{-\lambda_i\}$. The later on other hand amounts to 
changing the sing of the horizontal component $\Delta_k$ of the Anderson
pseudovector. Therefore it is the implication of TR symmetry of JW Hamiltonian 
that corresponding to every winding number $n_W$.
there is a winding number $-n_W$ irrespective of whether $r$ is even or odd. 
Therefore the winding numbers are symmetrically distributed around zero. 
Now let us argue that the possible values of $n_W$ are bounded by the range 
$r$ of interaction. As can be seen in Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig} every time the
pairing function $\Delta_k$ vanishes, the Anderson pseudovector points vertically 
either to the south or to the north pole. For a $r+1$-spin interactions involving
a cluster of spins of range $r$ the maximum number of the zeros in the 1BZ produced
by combination first and $r$'th harmonics of $\sin$ function 
is simply $r$. This means that $|n_W|\le r$.
To see when the maximum number of zeros in $\Delta_k$ are realized, it is enough
to consider the case where $J_r\sim r\lambda_r \gg \lambda_1$. This limit ensures that
there are $2r+1$ zeros for $\Delta_k$ in the 1BZ which corresponds to maximal
winding $|n_W|=r$. On the other hand in this limit the secular equation~\eqref{secul.eqn}
reduces to $x^{-2r}=(r-1)/(r+1)$ which is always less than unity for every $r>0$
which realizes maximum number of MFs equal to $2r$.
As we saw the TR operation on JW fermions is equivalent to $\{\lambda_i\}\to\{-\lambda_i\}$.
This in the language of spin variables is equivalent to $\pi/2$ rotation around the
$z$-axis, ${\sigma^x}\to{\sigma^y},{\sigma^y}\to-{\sigma^x},{\sigma^z}\to{\sigma^z}$. By the JW dictionary this translates to
the language of MFs as $a\leftrightarrow b$. 
But the secular equation for $b$ MFs can be obtained from the secular equation 
for the $a$ MFs by $x\to x^{-1}$. Since this transformation exchanges the number
of solutions whose magnitude is less than unity with those whose magnitude is more than
unity, every state with $n_M$ MFs of type $a$ in e.g. left end under TR is mapped to 
a state with $2r-n_M$ MFs; i.e. $n_M\to 2r-n_M$. On the other hand TR maps $n_W\to -n_W$.
Therefore both upper and lower bounds of $2r+1$ possible integers $|n_W|\le r$ and
$0\le n_M\le 2r$ describe the same physical state. 
On the other hand both $n_M$ and $n_W$ are unique topological labels of the
same state, the mapping between the two sets must be one-to-one. Since the ends
of two chains of integers map to each other, we heuristically expect Eq.~\eqref{nWnM.eqn}
to hold for any $r$. 


Let us now discuss the case of odd values of $r=2p+1$ by way of induction. 
In this case there are even number of spins and hence the TR is not broken
which means that the resulting JW Hamiltonian is invariant under $\pi$PH 
transformation~\eqref{piPH.eqn}. The winding number changes when the gap function
$\Delta_k=\lambda_1\sin k +\lambda_r\sin ((2p+1)k)$ vanishes. If this gap function
vanishes at some point $k_*$ in the 1BZ, by the $\pi$PH symmetry, relation~\eqref{piPH.eqn}
it also vanishes at $\pi-k_*$. The sign of the
vertical component ${\varepsilon}_k$ at $k_*$ and $\pi-k_*$ are opposite as the $\cos$ functions
appearing in vertical component ${\varepsilon}_k$ of Anderson pseudovector
change sign upon when going from $k_*$ to $\pi-k_*$ when $r$ is odd. 
Now starting from the XY model ($p=0$) and
focusing only in the right half of 1BZ with $k>0$, at $k=0$ and $k=\pi$ the
Anderson vectors point to north and south poles respectively
(Fig.~\ref{multiwind.fig}-f) which means that
in the right half of 1BZ one picks up a half-integer winding. 
Since for every $k_*$ if the Anderson pseudovector points to say the
north pole the one at $\pi-k_*$ will point to the south pole, 
corresponding to every root $k_*$ of $\Delta_k$, an integer winding
is inserted to the right half of 1BZ. This means that always half-integer
windings are possible in the right half of 1BZ. Therefore the winding 
number picked over the whole 1BZ is an odd number. That is why in the 
right panel of Fig.~\ref{MFcolor.fig} we only have odd winding numbers.
The fact that for odd $r$, only even number of MFs and only odd $n_W$s
are possible is consistent with Eq.~\eqref{nWnM.eqn}. 
This line of reasoning implies that
in the simple case $p=0$ corresponding to XY (or Kitaev) chain, 
the $\pi$PH symmetry implies that in the topologically non-trivial case
there are actually two independent Majorana
end modes related by $A_j\leftrightarrow -(-1)^j A_j$.

It can be noticed that the $Z_2$ index defined by 
$\nu={\rm sign}({\varepsilon}_0){\rm sign}({\varepsilon}_\pi)$~\cite{Alicea},
gives $\nu=-1$ when $r$ is odd. However, $r$ is even, 
$\nu={\rm sign}(|J_r/J_1|-1)$. For even $r$, the $\nu=+1(-1)$ corresponds 
to even (odd) values of $n_W$.
The physical interpretation of $\nu$ is as follows: 
When $\nu=+1 (-1)$ the identity of Bugolons does not change (changes) 
from hole-like to particle-like when $k$ spans the range $[0,\pi]$. 
The presence of $\pi$PH symmetry for odd $r$ guarantees that the above
$Z_2$ index takes only one value $-1$. Breaking $\pi$PH allows for both
$\pm$ values. 























{\em Summary}. To summarize, we have presented an exactly solvable extension of the quantum
XY model that involves clusters of $r+1$ spins interaction of range $r$. 
The ensuing JW representation is a topological superconductor in BDI  class.
We showed that the TR operation of original spin variables translates to 
a sliding PH transformation of JW fermions, $\pi$PH. The presence of $\pi$PH
restricts the $Z$ winding numbers to odd integers only. 
The Bott periodicity~\cite{Kitaev2009} implies that there should exist similar restriction
on $Z$ invariants based on the $\pi$PH operator. 
It will be interesting
to search for possible higher dimensional generalizations of the role of $\pi$PH 
symmetry in electronic systems~\cite{FuKane,ReadGreen,Stone}. 
Array of magnetic nano-particles on a superconductor is described by an 
effective theory that includes $r=2$ hopping between the spinless fermions~\cite{Beenakker2015,Choy2011}
which may serve as potential experimental platform to materialize 3XY model.
